Award.AbstractNarration:
The Rolling Deck to Repository (R2R) program has revolutionized the way the Academic Fleet for oceanographic research goes about the process of data stewardship. In 2009, the NSF Oceanographic Instrumentation and Technical Services Program funded the R2R program as a 4-way collaborative effort between data services groups at Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory (LDEO), Scripps Institution of Oceanography (SIO), Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI) and Florida State University (FSU). The mission of the R2R Program was to document and preserve the underway data from every cruise in the U.S. academic research fleet. R2R's work plan included uploading and classifying the end-of-cruise data distributions from each vessel operator; publishing an online catalog of vessels, cruises, datasets, and science parties; preparing and submitting the data to the NOAA Data Centers for long-term preservation; assessing the quality of selected data sets and providing quality feedback to operators; creating a standard set of data products including quality-controlled ship-track navigation, geophysical profiles (gravity, magnetics, bathymetry), and real-time meteorology/near-surface oceanography; and developing an event logging application to document at-sea operations. The R2R program team worked in close collaboration with the University National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS) Office, vessel technicians, NOAA Centers, other NSF-funded ocean data systems, disciplinary specialists in the research community, and international partners. All UNOLS operating institutions, as well as the NSF-supported Coast Guard Cutter (CGC) Healy, now routinely submit their cruise data to R2R. R2R has achieved its primary objectives during its initial five years of operation. Renewed funding will enable transition from a "development" focus to an "operational" focus. Work in the next five years includes continued operation of core infrastructure developed in the first phase of funding, as well as selected new tasks designed to improve R2R's products and services in response to community feedback.

Benefits of R2R will extend to key stakeholders including vessel operators, research scientists,
cyberinfrastructure developers, funding agencies, and the general public. R2R will provide tools and feedback to help marine technicians improve data quality and documentation, and will free them from the need to maintain a local data archive. A central cruise catalog for the academic fleet will ensure that original field data from every cruise are routinely preserved and disseminated, improving access for scientists and the public and simplifying funding agency efforts to enforce data sharing requirements. Standardization of data acquisition procedures across the fleet will facilitate integration with observations from other platforms such as NSFs Ocean Observatories Initiative, while enabling new synthesis efforts for a global ocean that is vast and sparsely explored.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Oceanographic research conducted by the US academic community is supported by a fleet of research vessels that operate worldwide and year-round carrying several thousand scientists, students, technicians, observers, and crew to sea on over 300 cruises each year. Investigations across a full range of ocean science disciplines are supported, from impacts of global change on ocean chemistry and ecosystems, to the structure and dynamics of ocean circulation, to the nature of volcanic and earthquake processes at the global plate boundaries. Each vessel in the academic fleet routinely operates a suite of ?underway? environmental sensors that are generally run continuously to collect a wide variety of meteorological, water column, and seafloor/subseafloor data, regardless of the specific mission of each cruise. The data acquired with these sensors are of high scientific value for building global syntheses, climatologies, and historical time series of ocean properties, for ground truthing of satellite observations, as fundamental data constraints for global ocean models, and as core background data sets for a wide range of marine investigations.

To ensure the long-term preservation and open access to these oceanographic data resources, the Rolling Deck to Repository (R2R) Program, with funding support from this award, provides a suite of comprehensive data management services for the US Academic Research Fleet (ARF). R2R data services support the acquisition, documentation, distribution and preservation of the unique high value sensor data collected routinely with the ARF contributing to the quality of data acquired and ensuring these data are openly available to the broad research and education community.   Over the 5-year project period, data acquisition was supported with near realtime quality control of Meteorological and Thermosolinograph data via the Shipboard Automated Meteorological and Oceanographic System (SAMOS) initiative serving 13 different ships during 867 cruises.  The R2R event log, which is provided to support at-sea documentation of data acquisition events such as sampling activities, was used on 219 cruises from 15 ships. Post cruise, environmental sensor data from all cruises conducted with the ARF from 2014 up to 2019 were documented, published, and archived with open public access to all released data provided through the R2R Cruise Catalog. The combined total number of new data sets added to the ARF data collection over this period are from 1,484 science cruises conducted on 25 ships in service over all or part of this period with 16,681 datasets published and archived. As part of R2R data documentation services, post-cruise automated quality assessment was completed for a suite of core data types with 3710 datasets evaluated and R2R standard data products were generated for navigation, geophysical and water column data totaling 3006 products created.

With these services, the R2R program has benefited a range of stakeholders including vessel operators, research scientists, funding agencies, and the general public.  R2R services benefit marine technicians and vessel operators with tools and feedback to support optimal operation of select sensors, and freeing them from the need to maintain an institutional data archive.  R2R services aid scientists while at sea with tools for documenting data acquisition activities, and post-cruise with data preservation and distribution services that relieve scientists of their responsibilities for data sharing.  R2R services support the funding agencies, simplifying efforts to enforce data sharing requirements, and the general public, providing open access to research data acquired with public funds. Finally, R2R data management services support the advance of scientific knowledge and discovery broadly, ensuring that the unique and high value oceanographic research data that are routinely acquired with the U.S. Academic Research Fleet are documented and preserved for new scientific inquiry long into the future.
